Reviews.Content: We booked this hotel as a hotel/flight combo and were not disappointed. The location was perfect (at least for us). We were able to take the metro (2 euro per person) to the hotel in about 30 or so minutes. We took the pink line to the blue line to the yellow line. Sounds complicated but was really easy. Ventura Rodriguez is the stop right outside the hotel which made it so easy to get around town. Plaza De Espana is a short walk from the hotel (roughly 10 minutes) and Temple Debod is about a 15 minute walk. We stayed on the 12th floor and had a lovely view with the Palacio Real in view. It only took us about 20 minutes to walk to the Palacio Real but you could tube it if you wanted (Opera is the stop you'd need). Also, if you decide to take the Madrid Vision hop on/off tour, the bus lets you off really close to the hotel. If you walk toward Plaza De Espana, you will come across several restaurants from cheap (Burger King) to more expensive. We ate at Cafe & Te' which is sort of cheap to mid range. I really liked the hotel and location. The room is modern and nice. There are doors inside the room that you can close to keep out hallway noise. The hotel corridor lights come on when you enter it which was a nice green touch, otherwise they were really dim. The shower was lovely with a big shower head and also a hand held one that was great for washing hair. The bell hop showed us how to use the room and helped us with our luggage. The front desk was helpful and showed us where the hotel was on a map and then pointed out a couple of major sights. We wanted to use the pool but there was a £15 per day charge so were a bit disappointed by that. One last thing, there was a little convenience store just around the corner which was great for getting little things from. Also, I thought the bed was great. I had the best night's sleep and felt really refreshed. They also supply an abundance of great pillows so there was a selection for individual tastes. An added bonus was that there was a safe in the room as well as a mini bar.

Reviews.Title: “Not quite disappointed but nothing to rave about either”
Reviews.Author: CdnWT
Reviews.Content: The title of the review says it all. I echo a few sentiments that were expressed in previous reviews about this hotel. It was so average and low-key, there really isn't much to write about and I'm usually one to write quite extensive reviews. On the other hand, there isn't anything that requires major complaining either. Basically, this is your run-of-the-mill city centre hotel with average facilities, an average (overpriced) breakfast, average staff and an average room. That being said, they were obviously positive and negative. To get it out of the way, I'll start with the negative/neutral aspects so you're not left reading this thinking it's all about complaints and no substance. First and foremost, the location is average. Not quite in the middle of everything yet, not quite far enough that you would require riding the subway all the time to see the major sights of Madrid. If you're looking for a city centre location that's a little more quiet than say, a hotel situated a few minutes from the Prado or the Atocha Station area, this hotel represents a good choice amongst Madrid hotels. You're never more than a 10-minute walk from restaurants and some of the attractions, or worst case, a 10-minute metro ride, of which you will find a station literally within 100 steps of the hotel's entrance. Secondly, for a hotel that pretends to be 5-star and is rated as such, it doesn't deliver 5-star service or facilities. This would be a 4-star hotel at best in most western countries. The hotel doesn't have a concierge and the front desk suggestions were often off, especially for restaurants. After 2 questionnable dining reccomendations the first 2 nights, we simply relied on our guidebook on the 3rd night. The rooms were indeed renovated quite recently but I question the functionality and the quality of guest room furnishings. Laminate flooring, Laminated faux wood furniture, Plastic faux glass everywhere, it was very IKEA-esque (even felt a little cheaper) and certainly didn't feel like staying in a 5-star hotel. The advertised pillow menu on the hotel's website was nowhere to be seen. In addition, the so-called DreamMax bed by Melia is really nothing to write home about. After lying down the first time, I wondered if the hotel had just put the fancy sheets and pillows on top of an old mattress. Check done, it was indeed a brand new mattress but forget the "pillowtop" Melia advertises on its website, this was nowhere near as plush as Westin's heavenly bed, the Marriott Revive beds, etc. Perhaps it is better suited for Spanish clientele, because it had little padding, was stiff )and not in a good way) and in no way particularly comfy. The duver provided is not the soft, warm feather type you'll find in those other chains either, it is filled with synthetic fabric. No interactive TV (not that it mattered to us but it sure is expected in any so called 5-star hotel in the world). Limited toiletries (they only provide on bar soap, shampoo and body wash. Do not expect to find conditioner or body lotion here, there is none. Melia has a lot to learn from the other major international chain on that. I do not recall seeing an iron or board. That being said, the hotel was also applying its substandard facilities to the minibar pricing, I though 2 euros for bottled water was quite reasonable for a hotel and phone calls were not a rip-off which can often be the case in Europe. Thirdly, the breakfast, charged at 26 Euros per person, was absolutely nowhere near worth that much. Limited hot selection which granted, is not common in Europe but at such a price, should have been provided for overseas visitors. Breakfast room staff could not crack a smile and they finally came to serve coffee while we were about to leave. Either they were understaffed but it felt like the two employees there that morning just lacked motivation. Finally for the negatives, the pool area hours were limited. During the month of August, the facility is simply closed on week-ends. In a seasonal hotel, ok maybe, but in the middle of the tourist season in Madrid, that's just cheap. The fact that they charge is also a bit ridiculous. Now, for the good parts. The hotel's cleanliness was examplary. A lot of North American properties could learn a lesson from these guys. The A/C kept the room well cooled in the midst of +40 celcius temperatures in Madrid. The shower was one of those nice "rainshower" type. The bellman was always on the ball to help you and most opened the door for you which gave it a touch of class. The internet access, just by the reception desk, is decently priced at 4 Euros per 30 minute period. The lobby and lounge area were quite attractively decorated and felt quite a bit more luxurious than the rooms. Note that the staff, even though they weren't quite on the spot with their recommendations, were prompt to respond to service request, such as when I called for a feather pillow. Housekeeping is good at respecting the do not disturb sign, even when we slept late (until nearly noon). However, on a funny side, I took away the DND sign one morning so the maid would be aware that we wanted cleaning and 2 minutes later, she entered without knocking and yelled at us for taking it off while not being ready to leave. I don't know if I should call this efficiency or being just plain rude but we laughed it off. The LCD TV had a good selection of international channels in Spanish, German, French and English. Overall, this was good value given the rate we paid (pre-paid on Sol Melia's website) but given the reputation of the chain, it was a little underwhelming. A lot of the facilities were closed during our stay and the staff, although efficient, wasn't overly friendly or helpful. That being said, they weren't rude either. The rooms felt cheap and they are small, although if you didn't know that rooms, even in major hotels, are small in European city centres, and you complain about it, you're probably better staying in North America. Note that rooms with 2 beds are always 2 single beds pushed together. I'd say, go for it if you think you're getting good value (100 Euros or less?) but don't expect a glamourous hotel with white glove service. It's a run-of-the-mill, city centre business hotel, nothing more, nothing less. Happy travels!

Reviews.Title: “Overpriced”
Reviews.Author: kama0529
Reviews.Content: The hotel was just okay. The rooms were clean and modern, yet very small. One of our rooms was a triple room, which was the same size as the double room but had an extra bed crammed in it (and cost an extra £60 a night more than the double). The wardrobe space was minimal, and if staying more than a weekend it was not enough. The food was totally disgusting - the soup was warm and had a film of thick oil floating on the top. However what really riled me was that we had to pay £15 to use the hotel pool (per person) per 24 hours - even as hotel guests! On top of this, we were told we had to wear swimming caps in the pool - which cost another £2 each. All in all, for a one hour swim we had to pay £85 (as there were 5 of us)! A 5 star hotel this is NOT!

Reviews.Title: “I liked it.”
Reviews.Author: libbyjibbs
Reviews.Content: The bedroom was lush. I particularly like the fancy lights under the tops of the tables. You could set it to what colour you like. The bed was massive and really comfy, and the bathroom was lovely too.

Reviews.Title: “Good Hotel and worth the stay”
Reviews.Author: Sheraz1
Reviews.Content: We (Mrs and I) went to Madrid for a weekend break. We have stayed in a number of 5* hotels over the last few years and were not disappointed with the Melia. The Melia is located just off the Gran Via in Madrid with very easy access to the Metro. The Metro stop Ventura Rodriguez is literally on your doorstep although we tended to walk pretty much everywhere. The Melia building is not exactly the height of architectural splendor, however the decor and rooms were stunning. Very trendy. The hotel rooms are, however slightly small. The bathroom contains his and her sinks with a sliding door separating the wash area and bath/toilet area. Very nice bed. One issue that we did have is that the Melia is described as being right on a Plaza when it is not. The nearest Plaza is Plaza Espana, which is a couple of minutes walk away. There are also shops and restaurants a couple of minutes walk away. Nearby attractions include the Temple Debod, Teleferico, Gran Via, Plaza Espana and the Palace. Overall a very good place to stay in order to explore the delights of Madrid.

Reviews.Title: “More than 3 but definitely less than a 4, maybe a 3.5”
Reviews.Author: PhTravelling_Guy
Reviews.Content: Smallish standard rooms at 25 sqm. (Not as small as some hotels I've stayed in in New York City, though.) I could move around but not much. I like the motion sensor that turns on the light in closet as well as those that turn on the lights in the hallways. The bathroom was fine. The two double sinks, the glass door between the sink and the rainshower are nice touches. (The operation of the faucets can be a bit confusing. You have to pull up. Turning them left to right does not work.) I could do without the kaleidoscope of changing colors in the bed side desks. (At least you can turn them off.) I could likewise do with more illumination from the desk lamp and the bedside reading lamps. While the aforesaid lights may be modern and trendy, they're not exactly practical. Have I mentioned that the entire hotel was renovated in 2008? One small nitpick about house keeping. I arrived back in my room one night to find a cleaning rag left on the bathroom countertop. Mistakes do happen but still.... Average breakfast. Definitely not great, as the variety is limited and the offerings do not change from day to day. That having been said, I especially liked the donuts (pretty close to Krispy Kreme in taste) and the fruits in the shot glasses. They have churros on offer but you have to order the chocolate separately. Location was good. Right beside the Ventura Rodriguez Metro Station and a short walk to Plaza Espana and the Temple of Debod. There are also a variety of eating places (form McDonalds to more elaborate restaurants) around the hotel, not to mention the El Corte Ingles up the street.

Reviews.Title: “excellent hotel - would go back in a second!”
Reviews.Author: star001
Reviews.Content: I have nothing but good remarks for this hotel - the bad reviews I can only put down to being prior to the revamp or written by really finicky people! We got the metro from the airport to the hotel - alighting the train at sol (though we found out on the walk to the hotel that Rodriguez station was practically outside the hotel!) & could see the hotel from here as its quite tall. Word of warning to anyone that decides to take the metro & walk to the hotel; the hotel is along the road, but the entrance down a side turning.... not an issue for safety or anything but we actually walk passed it because we were expecting the entrance along the roadside! The building itself, from the outside, is quite dated - but then it's pretty hard to change that once its built. Reception is lovely & very trendy - all red and black with large glass chandeliers, leather couches, thick pile rugs and single lily's. Check in was a breeze and the reception was staff were really friendly & helpful. We were given top floor (12) and room 1224!! I loved being this high up - the city views at night with all the lights were great. Bar area really sumptuous & toilets very clean, breakfast area is also very nice - though we didn’t actually eat at the hotel. Hallways to the rooms were pretty trendy too - carried on the red, black & white theme with marble art deco statues and the lighting was censored. Walkways were lit at ground level and when you walked into the hallway overhead lights came on- slightly dimmed to avoid that awful brightness you can get. Really nice ambience. I adored the room!!! Some people I notice have complained that the lighting was ait gadgety and it was - but I thought it was fun. I liked the lighting either side of the bed that changed colour and could be set at whichever you preferred, I like the massive flat screen telly on the wall and the glass tables and the large screen prints instead of stuffy mass produced paintings, & that all the lights could be controlled from the bed. The bed was large & massively comfortable with a menu of different pillows should you not like the 6 that were already supplied. Bathroom was great too - the usual complimentary toiletries were supplied (shampoo, shower gel, soap, toothpaste & brush, shoe shine) and plenty of towels. Dual sinks were a nice bonus and I loved the shower which had one of those heads that are as large as a plate and makes it feel like rain. Also had a separate shower head for washing hair over the bath which was handy too. Bath and toilet are separated from the sink area by a frosted glass door & there is a switch on the wall which pipes the tv into speakers there so you can catch the news or listen to music in the bath/shower. Enough storage space - the main hanging area splits the small corridor to the room and the bathroom, with doors on both sides so that clothes can be reached from either in the bathroom or the corridor (the whole wall of the corridor is a mirror). The rail is a light also which illuminates on a sensor also. Wi-fi connection available and free safety deposit box in the room. (which is big enough to put a netbook in - I had this query myself before I went) plenty of plug sockets, in areas I actually need them.... like near a mirror! There is a club about 2mins walk but I never heard any noise from it or outside at all. (maybe because we were on 12th floor?) but the club was definitely sound proof as you couldn’t hear music passing by it at 1/2am either. Only noise we heard was the cleaners in the morning but it wasn’t an ungodly hour so it wasn’t an issue. Couldn’t really hear much from the neighbours either. All the sites were really close by - within walking distance so we didn’t use the metro as much as we thought we might, really only for the airport run and when we went to the theme park. At €115 Per room per night this hotel was excellent value. Hope this is of help to anyone reading this but feel free to contact me if you need any details I haven’t covered!

Reviews.Title: “Nice business hotel”
Reviews.Author: FrenchTraveler001
Reviews.Content: Renewed in 2008, the hotel tries to pretend boutique, despite its huge size and its architecture from the 80s. It didn't manage too well, though everyting looks a bit fake. Beds are ultra-comfortable, and despite the amazing of light switches, they are quite intuitive and you can easily manage to turn lights off. I was on the last floor (the 12th), but despite this, some street noise could be heard in the room -it was not really annoying, but yet not sound-proof enough. Service is OK, not more.

Reviews.Title: “Designer Objetcs with No Practical Use”
Reviews.Author: TEMAMER
Reviews.Content: I selected the Hotel because it was recently renovated. I did not know that apparently they employed for the renovation an Architect which had no sense of practical use. I could almost not read in the room because of silly desinger lamps which gave not enough light. On the other side the nighttable had a colourchangig light which you could change from red to blue to green and so on. Who needs it ? The windows unfortunately where the old ones, so even on the 10th floor day and night you heard the heavy traffic noise. The bathroom was equipped with silly little sinks where you could hardly wash the hands also because the waterpipe was located on the left side a few centimeters from the porcelain sinkwall. In the WC they had installed a bidet but had forgotten to apply a soapholder nearby ! So beware of designer hotels !

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Rafaelj
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stay 3 nights in Nov 2008; the hotel has being recently remodeled in the inside. We loved the modern décor of the rooms and the hallways. The staff is very friendly and helpful. The Ventura metro station is like 30 meters away. I would stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent city centre hotel”
Reviews.Author: Sussexmember
Reviews.Content: A group of 4 colleagues stayed for 4 days for a conference. The hotel is very comfortable for business travellers - has all the facilities you need (except perhaps irons in the rooms - but they bring them when you need them). Seen poor reviews of the breakfast but we had a very different experience - a wide variety of hot and cold food, fruits etc - and hot coffee! Rooms reasonably priced for city centre location and staff helpful and friendly. Excellent hotel for business or leisure break

Reviews.Title: “Loved the hotel room! Hated the breakfast”
Reviews.Author: Libby15
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Melia for 3 nights. We booked through the Sol Melia website as there was a special offer (about £60 a night for a king size bed) which including breakfast for one day - which was not good! This was the only downside of our stay. The hotel is being refurbished and re-decorated. The reception area is modern-luxe and our bedroom was outstanding. We had a great view of Madrid, a wide-screen wall-mounted TV, a huge and comfy bed, a luxury bathroom with a powerful large-head shower and his/hers basins. The whole room was newly decorated in a contemporary style with a lot of beech and glass, and lots of comfortable furniture, and lots of storage space, and modern, unusual lighting. The staff were friendly and helpful and quick to respond to our request for tea, chocolates (complementary!), iron and to fix the switch in the bathroom when it jammed. We also got a free late check-out. We would not hesitate to stay at this hotel again, and were thrilled with the value for money offered. Another small downside is that the hotel is being refurbished and we ocassionally heard workmen, but they were usually discreet and the sound was not loud enough to bother us.

Reviews.Title: “Good service and breakfast but rooms need renovation”
Reviews.Author: GranReserva
Reviews.Content: I booked two nights in Melia Princesa knowing the fact that in Spain 5 stars does not usually mean luxury as there is a 5 GL class for top hotels. However, 99€ (+breakfast 19€ pp) +tax 7% was quite good value in September. Some hotel brokers sell this hotel for 170€ (bf incl). The hotel is a terrible looking 1960's Soviet Union style building with at least 20 floors but hotel rooms are located only from 4rd to12th floor which means that most rooms do not have a view to the city. Lobby is quite attractive with nice sofas. We had a good view to the Royal Palace from the 9th floor. Furniture in the room was not the original, perhaps from the 1980's - IKEA style. I think it's a bit risky that a large brand chain like Sol Melia lets their clients to see rooms in such condition. Bed comfort was OK, TV set decent, bathroom very small. Room size (standard room) is reasonable, but could be larger for a 5 star hotel. Wall papers were dirty and ugly. Walls and furniture were green and blue. Breakfast buffet is very good, also the bf room is nice. Sol Melia MAS card holder gets a free bf for a companion which is very good benefit. 10€ for excellent bf is good value. Service in reception is very good and professional, some Spanish words help a lot. Also doormen are very polite and helpful. Location is quite OK for visits to the Royal Palace and Plaza Mayor, but I prefer the other part of the Old City where the main museums and Retiro Park are. Calle Princesa (street) is not as noisy as Gran Via. Last time I lived there and will never do that again. I got mixed feelings about this hotel - room was at 2-3 star level, but everything else was fine. I am quite sure that the hotel will soon start a major renovation project. Before the renovation starts, the hotel could offer a free entrance to the pool and sauna (now 15€ +tax 7%) to keep customers happy. Spanish hotel rating system needs some updating. Once a hotel has been awarded 5 stars in 1960's, seems that it will never be downgraded. I also spent recently three nights in Gran Hotel Canarias which is rated 4 GL. The room was luxurious, B&O flat TV etc.

Reviews.Title: “nothing special”
Reviews.Author: helcia
Reviews.Content: Terrible decoration at the entrance, unfriendly check-in, no service (although personal avaiable). Room size ok, but old stuff. Bathroom so la-la. Lobby bar worn out. Breakfast is fantastic though! Location not. Will not repeat.

Reviews.Title: “Great experience!”
Reviews.Author: JessSanDiego_CA
Reviews.Content: I stayed at Melia Madrid Princesa for almost a week on a business trip. Overall, I had a great experience at this hotel. The staff were friendly and helpful, the rooms were nice, and the breakfast buffet was awesome! Also, the gym was pretty good - small, but better than many American hotels. The bar in the lobby is also nice and they serve nice snacks when you order drinks. The location of the hotel is great - about 2 blocks before Princesa turns into the famous Gran Via. You can walk to most of the popular tourist spots. I stayed at a different hotel (Hotel Emperador) for a few days after checking out of this one (for personal vacation purposes), and everyday I wished I were back at this one! The only thing I didn't like about this hotel were the somewhat creepy looking flower displays in the lobby (but those aren't important)!

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Customer Service”
Reviews.Author: dicanio10
Reviews.Content: I used to stay at the Princesa when in Madrid on business but lately I have been staying at their sister hotel, Los Galgos which is infinitely inferior. This trip, I insisted on the Princesa and I am glad I did. The staff were most friendly and helpful and the rooms are certainly bigger and better than the Galgos for the same price. Well equipped 4 piece bathroom and shower and most rooms have a decent view. Bar and restaurant are of the highest quality although I normally choose to eat out. There are numerous restaurants and bars nearby and their is a Metro station right outside which has been recently refurbished. Plaza de Espana and Arguelles stations are also within 2 or 3 minutes walk with connections to most parts of Madrid. The area itself is not too bad with the Plaza de Espana and Palacio Real minutes walk away and a spacious park next to the palace. I never feel threatened walking around at night as it's quite busy and most locals tend to come out around 11 at night. However, on my last morning, I fell victim to the old 'distraction robbery' nearby. I felt something splash on the back of my jacket and a stranger appeared to 'help' me clean my jacket. Meanwhile, his accomplice had run off with my briefcase. This was near Arguelles around 10:30am in broad daylight but when I got back to the Princesa to see if they could help, I was bowled over by their assistance. I explained what had happened and one of the staff took my jacket away and cleaned it up a treat while the general manager helped me report the incident. I was very grateful for their help and also grateful that I wasn't harmed as the manager said that this was a common occurence in the area and they usually pull a knife out! This is about the fifth time I have stayed here and it wouldn't put me off staying here again. The staff are great, just have your wits about you and stay on the main streets!

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Value”
Reviews.Author: smjak02
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for 4 nights in July as part of a touring holiday. Top value including an excellent buffet breakfast. We were on the top floor with a great view out over of the city. Room facilities were fine including free internet. A problem in the room with the connection was dealt with speedily if not entirely satisfactorily. Car was parked at the front by staff saving car park fees. Room service good although slightly surprised to be informed that they didnt speak English, as "this is Spain". Took me back a few years, was fun managing. Old gent brought in with good humour, was almost correct! Good location.

Reviews.Title: “A Fab Hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I stayed at this hotel for a weekend away and would have loved to have stayed longer. The room was fantastic with a lovely view of the mountains in the distance and had everything we needed - was very luxurious! Breakfast was the best ever and the bar very good. Only downfall was the reception staff not sure if rude or could not speak very good english! My Spanish not that good!!! I would thoroughly recommend you stay here!

Reviews.Title: “A dissapointment”
Reviews.Author: davidstoplar
Reviews.Content: Our stay here, just before Easter 2005, was a dissapointment. We were expecting a top class hotel, comparable to other Melias we have stayed in in Spain, but this was a big let down. Our first room, a standard double, was a shabby, gloomy affair on the top floor. We changed to a superior room which was a little better, supposedly modernised, just with a different colour scheme. Heavy outsize drapes and grubby net curtains, none of them hung properly with enough hooks, made opening the windows difficult. The sink sat outside the rest of the bathroom which had a swinging glass partition rather than a door. The general appearance of the room was faded with no attention to detail at all. The rooms are in long dark corridors which are stiflingly hot. On the plus side, the other public areas, including the restaurant are classy and breakfast excellent. The staff were friendly although reception seemed bemused that there might be any problem. The hotel is a little way from the Golden Triangle of art galleries, but well placed for the Plaza Mayor, Royal Palace and old part of the city.

Reviews.Title: “Not a bad hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Melia Madrid Princesa for about one week in April 2004. We were in town on business so the nice business centre was much appreciated. I have never had a better breakfast buffet (included in the cost of the room) and I have tried a lot! The location is good although it would have been nicer to be closer to the art galleries, etc. Our rooms were very nice but my colleague had difficulty sleeping due to noise one night. The hotel said there was nothing they could do about it which was very frustrating. We would probably return although I am seeking a similar hotel closer to the Prado.

Reviews.Title: “Melia Madrid Good Location”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Great location. Lots of shopping and restaurants close by. Staff was excellent and always helpful. Rooms were above average for europe. I would stay at this hotel again.

Reviews.Title: “Miserable customer service!”
Reviews.Author: LucasLondon_UK
Reviews.Content: Location is very convenient as close to Plaza de Espana. The reception area are good, but the service is terrible. When I wanted to use the gym on a Sunday at 12.00 it was closed (on Sundays it is open for 3 hours anyway), but there was no sign. When I asked at the reception, they sent me back and told me somebody would come (they state everywhere "Our commitment: 100% satisfaction in 15 minutes!). But nobody showed up even after 20 minutes. When I called the reception from my room, they said that there had been an emergency with the lady who opens the gym and that she had to go to the hospital... But why did they send me back to the gym and let me wait for 20 minutes if this happened already the night before? and why did they not put up a sign that the gym is closed? This sounds like a very dumb excuse and certainly not tolerable for a 5 star hotel. So if you care for proper service, this is definitely the wrong hotel with this customer attitude, apart from the fact that their big promise of 100% customer satisfaction is a joke.

Reviews.Title: “Nice place to stay. Not a luxurious 5 star, though.”
Reviews.Author: damcone
Reviews.Content: Just stayed at the Melia Madrid Princesa Feb 7-13, 2004, while it is a nice hotel in a nice location, I think it fell just short of the 5 star they say it is. It wasn't as luxurious as a 5 star should be and was just a really nice business hotel. Loved the bar for after dinner drinks/conversations. Spa treatments were a little lacking as they seemed understaffed....Would recommend a stay here, however.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic Hotel. Perfect Stay.”
Reviews.Author: RFJC
Reviews.Content: I first visited the Melia Princesa in 1999. I liked it so much I got married there in 2002 (if you can reserve Suite no 303 for a special occasion it really is amazing - best hotel suite in Spain for my money). I've now stayed there 7 times and I love the place. The best thing about it isn't the rooms or the food, it's the staff. They are all really lovely people most of whom have worked there all their working lives. If you can get a room on the 11th or 12th floors, go for it as the view over the city and the Royal Palace is breathtaking. My last trip was January 04 and the hotel has opened its new spa and leisure centre which is excellent. I thoroughly recommend this hotel. You won't be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect place”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I do not regret having found the Melia Madrid Princesa though the internet. My wife and I spent 5 days in Mardid out of the Melia Madrid Princesa and everything was perfect. The Metro was just around 75 yards from the front door and from there everything was so accessible. The staff were pleasant, courteous and attentive. Our room was tastefully furnished, though expectedly not extravagant. But clean, well lit, comfortable and not odorous. (Sometime you smell the old carpets ) THe bathroom was great ( according to my wife ) with mirrors and flowers and all others for the lady, including the bidet. The breakfast buffet was stupendous, serving spanish to continental fare in a huge room that bespoke of the warmth of a house.No regrets. will go back!

HotelInfo.Name: Melia Madrid Princesa
HotelInfo.Address: C/ Princesa, 27, 28008 Madrid, Spain
